Duncan, Elizabeth Margaret
102 Pike Road, R.R. 5
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire in pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as anyone else. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If you have any particular events or experiences to relate, please describe them.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have already answered this, and would be willing to do so again, please put a check mark here (X) and one will be sent to you.

Later this year, some of these new questionnaires will be prepared at Saskatchewan Archives. They will cover other subjects which you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and please names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Elizabeth Margaret Duncan
2. Your address: 403 Pike Road, R.R. 5 New Westminster, B.C.
3. Date: ..............................................................
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Ontario Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Carpenter
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) December 1874
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may answer "I was in..." etc., "I was 17 months old."

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

"I think my father came here to make more money and to see what went on over the hill."

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

3. Date: ...........................................
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Ontario Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation? .......................................................
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) January 1884
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to sign.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
10. How did you learn about the Platts (Thonka cattle people)? (Including about it?)

I think my father came west to make more money
and to see what went on over the hill.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Some of them thought my father and mother were just a little bit young.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? E.P.R. railroad

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the trip, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Regina

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Your Street, Calgary

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I lived in Lumsden and Valdort

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My father as a carpenter
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Some thought my father and mother were just a little bit young.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

13. What means of transportation did you use? C.P.R. railroad

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the trip, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Regina

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Your story

17. Mention any jobs or work you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I lived in Brandon and Virden

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My father as a carpenter
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Two or three times a year

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

By Father mother, aunts, cousins and friends came west and homesteaded near us.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

One thing I can remember although I was only three years old is a small boy two years old a son of my father's cousin, his mother being dead he lived with his aunt and grandmother. In 1885 she wandered away from her grand mother's house and was never seen again. I can remember the friends and relatives searching the prairie for days but no trace of them was ever found so every person who had been in search of child though I was walked with my mother until my small step could go me further. An older brother of this child tried to aid his grandmother for years without success. He died in a hospital and a year after his death the ground that found his bones while riding through the hills was visited by friends, etc., how often? How far? How long? How many? How many?

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Our mode of travel for business and visiting was walking, horse or wagon or horseback.

My father mother, aunts, cousins and friends came west and homestead near No.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

One thing I can remember although I was only three years old in a small log cabin with my father, causing him much worry during the winter months. In 1885 he wanted away from the grand mother's house and was never seen again. I can remember the friends and relatives searching the prairie for days but no trace of them was ever found so every friend and relative in search of child though I was walked with my mother until my small life could go no further. On our farther trip this time to add to this grand adventure I found myself in a rugged and mountainous country. We traveled about much in the early years? (For business attending church, visiting friends etc.) How? By what means of travel?

Our mode of travel for business and visiting was walking, horse or oxen and wagon or homestead.
